title: A Bird Song Detector for improving bird identification through Deep Learning: a case study from Donana
author: Alba Marquez-Rodriguez (University of Córdoba), Miguel Angel Mohedano-Munoz (Estación Biológica de Doñana), Manuel J. Marín-Jimenez (University of Córdoba), Eduardo Santamaría-García (Estación Biológica de Doñana), Giulia Bastianelli (Estación Biológica de Doñana), Pedro Jordano (Estación Biológica de Doñana), Irene Mendoz (Estación Biológica de Doñana), ...
relevance_why: The application of deep learning for automated bioacoustic monitoring can inspire similar methods in audio processing tasks for other domains, including speech and music.
background: The task involves using deep learning to classify bird vocalizations in audio recordings from Doñana National Park, aiming to improve species detection and monitoring.
contribution: This paper introduces a multi-stage pipeline that utilizes a Bird Song Detector to enhance bird vocalization identification, achieving improved classification accuracy compared to existing methods.
technical_comparison: Previous methods relied heavily on manually engineered features and struggled with overlapping sounds. This work improves by integrating a specialized bird vocalization detector to isolate relevant audio segments before classification.
key_innovation: The unique aspect of this method lies in using a hierarchical detection and classification process, which reduces noise interference and improves accuracy in species identification.
real_world_impact: This approach can enhance biodiversity monitoring efforts, providing valuable data for conservation strategies in threatened ecosystems.

new_terms.Passive Acoustic Monitoring: **Passive Acoustic Monitoring (PAM)** refers to the technique of using audio recording devices to gather information about wildlife without direct observation, facilitating long-term ecological studies.
new_terms.Intersection over Union (IoU): **Intersection over Union (IoU)** is a metric used to evaluate the overlap between two bounding boxes, commonly used in object detection tasks to assess prediction accuracy.
